messageBody:
>So said Eric Armstrong on 2003-06-13 --------------------
>J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
>>>So said Kevin Klinemeier on 2003-06-11 --------------------
>>>Can you test the behavior of whatever it is that reads the counter
>>>internally? What is it supposed to do with this counter value?
>>
>> ...and is using *that* thing more complex than just having the 'get'
>method? Is it worth the effort?
>>
>It's an interesting conunundrum.
>
>At least one design principle dictates the avoidance of get methods.
>Allen Holub is proponent of that practice, I believe -- the theory
>being that you keep sending information to objects until some
>object has enough information to carry out the desired operation.

I would be interested to know how Mr. Holub implements a View in a web application. While the Controller pushes the data into the View Template, the Template still needs to stick the customer's first name *here*, last name *there* and so on... this entails some way of either (1) retrieving the data or (2) allowing the object to display its data, however you prefer to look at it.

I suppose one possibility is to hand the model object a stream on which to write itself. Smalltalk does this quite a bit. The bad news is that different applications display the same data differently, so the model is the wrong place to add the method "printYourselfOn(..)". We could build specialized Presentation Objects that know how to print themselves on the view, but a typical implementation would look like this:

CustomerPresentationObject
initialize(customerModelObject)
@model = customerModelObject

printYourselfOn(viewTemplate)
viewTemplate.firstNameField.setText(firstName)
...
viewTemplate.orderTotalField.setText(orderTotal)

firstName
return @... # No special formatting here

orderTotal
return CurrencyFormatter.format(@...)

No matter how you package it, some object has to grab data from the model and format it onto the view. How does Mr. Holub implement this?

<snip />
>Of couse, any desire to keep such methods out of the production
>objects leads to interesting and problematic design issues, but
>it might be worth adding additional methods like:
> eventNotificationListIncludes(EvenListener el)

This is just a dressed-up "get" method. It allows the caller to query about the callee's state in order to make a decision. In this case, the decision is "test passes".

I think this is the right separation of responsibilities: the test should decide whether it passes, not the object under test. However, how does the test want to decide?

Option 1.
assertTrue(eventSource.contains(listenerIJustAdded))

Option 2.
eventSource.add(listener)
eventSource.triggerEvent()
assertTrue(listener.heardEvent())

I prefer option 1, even if it adds a method that the event source wouldn't otherwise need. That's my choice. I think it's easier (on the whole) than the maintenance issues that option 2 implies.

>(Open question: Should such a method return a boolean or throw
>an exception??)

I think clearly it should answer "yes" or "no". The name is "contains...", which is a query. In Ruby, it'd be "containsListener?" Clearly a "yes" or "no" answer.

Take care.
